Dear Rodney John Weaver:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Between October and November 2022, when Youth A resided at
the facility, Youth A swallowed a razor in attempt of suicide. Staff
did not see youth swallow the razor, but did not seek medical
attention. Youth A was bleeding from the rectum and could not
swallow for days. Youth A was taken to the hospital 5 days later
and suffered GI injuries.
Investigation This complainant was transferred to DCWL and assigned on
09/092024.
The complainant is Anonymous.
Chief Administrator was interviewed at the facility on
09/10/2024. Chief Administrator recalled this incident involving
Youth A. He said Youth A was at the facility from 2022 to 2023.
He reports Youth A had AWOLed from campus on the day in
question, which was 11/05/2022 and returned to campus on
11/06/2022 . When she returned, Youth A was searched and there
was nothing found on her. Later that evening, Youth A told staff
she had swallowed a razor. Youth A’s room was searched, and
nothing was found. Youth A was laughing and acting fine. He said
Youth A was known to make up things and they were not sure if
she was being truthful. Youth A was examined by Nurse the next
day and did not have any complaints. Nurse and staff monitored
Youth A for symptoms and when Youth A complained of stomach
cramps, she was taken to the hospital. Youth A had an x-ray
completed at the hospital that showed she did have a razor in her
abdomen. The Doctor recommended a liquid diet and said Youth
A would pass it in her stool. He does not recall she had any GI
issues when she passed the razor, a week later.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed at the facility on
09/10/2024. Youth B and Youth C reported no concerns regarding
2

staff supervision and care. Youth B and Youth C reported feeling
safe and all their needs are being met.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 09/16/2024. Youth A
reported she was placed at the facility for 15 months. Youth A
recalled the incident and reported she had hidden a small razor in
the sleeve of her sweater that she obtained when she AWOLed
from the facility. She was in her room when she swallowed the
razor blade. She told staff (unknown who) that she swallowed the
razor blade, but they thought she was pretending and said the
staff didn’t believe her. She recalls seeing the nurse and going to
the hospital several days later. She reported experiencing
stomach cramps but did not have any bleeding or vomiting. Youth
A said staff did search her and her bedroom.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
09/16/2024. Foster Care Worker reported she has been working
with Youth A for 6 months. Youth A is currently in an independent
living program and is doing very well. Foster Care Worker said
Youth A has never reported any concerns regarding her previous
placement.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility on 10/07/2024. Staff 2 has
been working at the facility for four years as a direct care worker.
Staff 2 recalled the incident involving Youth A. She could not recall
how she learned about the incident but remembered having to
check up on Youth A. She reported Youth A was being monitored
by staff and the nurse for several days until she passed the razor
in her stool. Youth A was being seen by the nurse and was taken
to the emergency room the following day. She said Youth A was
acting fine and did not report any discomfort. Staff 2 denied Youth
A had any vomiting or bleeding while being monitored. She
recalled Youth A was put on a liquid diet.
Nurse was interviewed at the facility on 10/07/2024. Nurse
reported she examined Youth A the following day, 11/07/2022,
after reporting she swallowed a razor and Youth A did not report
any pain, bleeding, discomfort or any other symptoms. On
11/08/2022 Youth A reported having abdomen pain and was taken
to the emergency room. An x-ray was completed, and it did show
Youth A had swallowed a razor blade. The hospital
recommended a liquid diet and to continue monitoring until the
razor passes in her stool. Youth A was monitored by Nurse and
staff until Youth A passed it in stool. Nurse denied Youth A had
any bleeding or vomiting while she was being monitored.
3

Documents reviewed:
• Incident report dated 11/06/2022. Youth A reported she had
swallowed a razor blade. A room search was completed,
and nothing was found. Youth A did not have any visible
injuries.
• Consulting physician form dated 11/07/2022. Youth A was
assessed by the Nurse for the possible swallow of a foreign
object. Nurse recommended staff monitor Youth A for
bowel pain, vomiting, or blood in stool.
• Hospital medical report for Youth A dated 11/08/2022.
Youth A was examined in the ER for swallowing a foreign
object. X-ray of the abdomen completed and revealed razor
in the abdomen area, recommended liquid diet until razor
passes through stool.
• Consulting physician form dated 11/16/2022. Youth A
passed foreign object. Nurse reported no blood in stool.
Youth A resumed normal diet.
• Facility policy for health services. Staff and Nurse screen
residents daily for signs of symptoms of an illness or injury.
Screenings include conditions related to physical,
emotional, mental, and spiritual needs of residents.
Appointments may be made for an evaluation by the
campus medical professional who visits weekly or a
community resource as necessary.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance per interviews with Youth,
staff, and medical documentation, Youth A swallowed a razor and
was not taken to the hospital until two days later after she started
having abdomen pain.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was offered regarding adding additional
information to the medical emergency policy for emergent needs.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Title qualifications
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
4

Allegation The Director told staff to “go with the flow” and remember, we
didn’t watch Youth A swallow anything.
About 10 years ago, Staff 1 watched youths showering together
and made comments about the youth's bodies.
Investigation Chief Administrator denied telling staff to say they did not watch
Youth A swallow a razor. He recalls asking if staff saw Youth A
have a razor.
Chief Administrator reported Staff 1 retired from the facility in
2019. He denied any reports or incidents involving Staff 1. He
reported Staff 1 worked at the facility for 32 years, was a “by the
book” staff member that followed policy and procedures, and he
never had to address any issues with her as a direct care staff.
Staff 1 worked in the detention center on the girl’s unit. Chief
Administrator reported the girl’s unit bathroom has three showers;
however, girls don’t shower at the same time and a staff member
stands outside the bathroom while the youth shower.
Youth B and Youth C both reported youths shower one at a time
and staff wait outside of the bathroom. Youth B and Youth C
denied any concerns regarding staff and expressed no issues
regarding the facility.
Youth A denied knowing Staff 1 and did not have any incidents
involving staff watching her while showering.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 10/07/2024. Staff 1
reported she worked at the facility for 32 years as a direct care
staff. She denied any discipline throughout her career at the
facility. Staff 1 worked in the detention center on the girl’s unit.
She denied ever making a comment about the youths’ bodies or
watching them while they shower. She said the bathroom has
three showers, and they would have two girls shower at the same
time, but that changed several years before she retired. She said
she would stand outside the bathroom with her back to the girls.
Staff 1 denied having any issues or reports by any of the youths
while she worked at the facility. Staff 1 was not working at the
facility during the incident involving Youth A.
Staff 2 did not express any concerns regarding Staff 1 or the
Chief Administrator. She denied witnessing or hearing any reports
regarding Staff 1 making any inappropriate remarks about girls
bodies while showering.
5

Documents Reviewed:
• There were no disciplinary actions in Staff 1’s file or
incident reports pertaining to Staff 1 watching youths
shower and making inappropriate comments.
• There were no disciplinary actions in Chief Administrator’s
file.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews with staff
there is insufficient evidence to support the allegations.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
